User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0

When downloading executables, Firefox offers a reduced dialog which only offers a "Save" button. Presumably it is conjectured (or even proven?) to reduce accidental malware installations. I think this can be done much better though with proper attention from UI people.

If the idea is to add extra clicks before letting the user execute the file, then this can be achieved by a checkbox (or two, or three). Ticking it (them) would enable the "Run download" option. Add as many as is thought to be necessary to have the malware reducing effect (I suspect just one).

If the idea is to delay the user, then just disable the Run button until the appropriate, about:config-tweakable delay has expired.

If the idea is to inconvenience the user so that they change their mind and don't download - well this would be a silly reason, I doubt that's the idea.

The current implementation requries me to save one-off EXEs (i.e. browse to my temporary "firefox exe dumpground"), then periodically clean it, and then browse to my usual download location for other files. Awful user experience.

Reproducible: Always
